section.title: Overview of tcp/ip v4
section.para: The unicast Internet Protocol is one of the oldest network protocols, commonly used today for LAN and WAN networks. Every hosthost gets a unique 32-bit ip-addressip-address, this is either static or received from a DHCP server. Internet networks contain several subnetssubnet. Those subnets used to be classfulclassful (A,B,C,D or E), but this wasted a lot of address space. Today we work with CIDRCIDR notation to determine network idnetwork id and host idhost id.
In a couple of years we will all be using IPv6! At least, that is what people say since 1995...

section.title: Internet and routers
section.para: The internet is a collection of routersrouter that act as gateways between different segmentssegment. Routers use their routing table to determine the route of tcp/ip packets. Routers are layer 3 devices, layer 2 contains bridgesbridge and switchesswitch, layer 1 is cabling with repeatersrepeater and hubshub. Layer 2 devices know your 48-bit unique in the world MACMAC address.

section.title: many protocols
section.para: For reliable connections, you use tcptcp, whereas udpudp is connectionless but faster. The icmpicmp error messages are used by pingping, multicast groups are managed by igmpigmp and the ip to mac resolution is done by the broadcast protocol arparp.
These protocols are visible in the protocol field of the ip header, and are listed in the /etc/protocols/etc/protocols file.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ grep tcp /etc/protocols tcp 6 TCP # transmission control protocol paul@laika:~$
section.para: Every host receives a hostnamehostname, usually placed in a DNS name space forming the FQDNFQDN or Fully Qualified Domain Name. Common application level protocols like SMTP, HTTP, SSH, telnet and FTP have fixed port numbers.
To find a port number, look in /etc/services/etc/services.
